metadata.title: Preventing imbalanced data from leading to abominable classification: A satellite imagery illustration | by Mitali Bhurani | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Preventing imbalanced data from leading to abominable classification: A satellite imagery illustration
metadata.description: When the occurrence of instances belonging to one class of a dataset is massive whereas, for the instances belonging to other class(es) it is one chance in a million, we call it imbalanced dataset…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Remote Sensing Tutorials by Canada Centre for Mapping and Earth Observation (or Canada Centre for remote Sensing), Natural Resources Canada
Remote Sensing Tutorials — Canada Centre for Mapping and Earth Observation (or Canada Centre for remote Sensing), Natural Resources Canada.
Have you asked why F1-Score is a Harmonic Mean(HM) of Precision and Recall?

all_paragraphs: When the occurrence of instances belonging to one class of a dataset is massive whereas, for the instances belonging to other class(es) it is one chance in a million, we call it imbalanced dataset.
“A good example is far better than a good precept.” ― Dwight L. Moody
Having said that, classic examples of imbalanced data are classifying emails as spam or ham, fraud detection, etc. You can also find datasets related to them on Kaggle.
Well, the answer is hidden in the question itself! Let me throw some light on it with a quote:
“When you look at the number of satellites, what they’re doing and what they represent, it is really a vision of trying to have the world in your clutches.”
This must have sounded somewhat philosophical. Here go the practical ones:

“Satellites record data in different parts of the light spectrum that we can’t see. And it’s that information that allows satellites to be so powerful in terms of looking at things like vegetation health, finding different kinds of geology that may indicate an oil deposit or some kind of mineralogical deposit that can be mined.”

“Scientists use satellites to track weather, map ice sheet melting, detect diseases, show ecosystem change… the list goes on and on. I think nearly every scientific field benefits or could benefit from satellite imagery analysis.”
To dig deeper into this, Wikipedia is here to help.

Note: If you are a newbie in remote sensing, then Remote Sensing Tutorials by Canada Centre for Mapping and Earth Observation (or Canada Centre for remote Sensing), Natural Resources Canada is a perfect resource for you.
Okay! Let’s now get our hands dirty in classifying a satellite image.

The intention here is simple, yet effective. We are interested in scouting out the urban areas (labelled as Built-up) from satellite imagery, shelving the rest part of the image (labelled as Non-Built-up). The monitoring of urban areas through satellite imagery is beneficial in urban planning, sustainable development and to get a quick update of urban area maps at the time of disaster. In addition, it is eminent in grokking the impact of urban expansion upon the ecosystem and surroundings.

I have used Sentinel-2A, Level-1C data downloaded from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) website with Moradabad, a city located in the western part of Uttar Pradesh, India, as my study area. Prior to anything else, pre-processing a satellite image is a must. However, Level-1C product is top-of-atmosphere reflectance data which is radiometrically and geometrically corrected along with being ortho-rectified.
Tidbit: Pre-processing a satellite image and pre-processing the data for machine learning estimators (mean removal and variance scaling, etc.) are like chalk and cheese i.e., they are not alike.

Four bands[2 (Blue), 3 (Green), 4 (Red), 8 (NIR)] were composited with 10m spatial resolution and clipped to the study area. The 4-band-10m composite and Built-up Mask of the study area were used for classification.

Considering binary classification problems, if the negative class has a substantially large number of instances than those of the positive class, then the model will always try to predict the negative class in order to achieve high accuracy. But that indeed will be misleading.
Let’s get an insight into the scenario with our dataset.
I used GDAL python package to fetch the raster bands of the composite as arrays and converted the data into CSV file format. However, this is not mandatory and was just done for convenience.
As is evident from the bar graph, our dataset is highly imbalanced with 81.86% of Non-Built-up (negative class) and only 18.14% of Built-up (positive class).

If we try to train our model on this kind of data, it will fall prey to something called as accuracy paradox. Elaborating more on this, our model will just try to reveal the underlying class distribution in disguise of accuracy.
There are several blogs on techniques to combat imbalanced classes. But, I found this one to be sparkling like a glazed disco ball.
I found the following techniques to be somewhat more appealing than the rest.
The focus of this blog will be on the first technique from the two listed above.
The problem is decomposed into 3 simple steps:
Having an overview of Decision Tree and Bagging (Bootstrap Aggregating) is a prerequisite before going ahead.

In layman’s term, Random Forest is an ensemble of decision trees usually used to “aptly” combat high variance (overfitting) of the decision trees. Unlike Bagging, Random Forests limit the features to be evaluated at each split, i.e., a random subset of features is used at each split, leading to decision trees that are highly non-correlated. Due to this reason, Random Forest is widely used in classification as well as regression tasks.
Let’s jump on the bandwagon and check how our model performs, taking the default parameters of Random Forest Classifier into account.

A model when trained on the whole input data, is told to predict the same input data, it performs like a genius. But it has actually become a crammer. When told to predict unseen data, it will terribly fail to produce desired results. This situation is called “overfitting”. To prevent this, we divide the data into train and test set where the model is kept deprived of the test set and trained on the train set. The performance of the model is then evaluated on the test set.

Before we train our model on the train set, we need to perform feature scaling to bring our data within a specific range so that the model doesn’t get biased towards a particular feature in response to a small change in its co-efficient or weight. It is important to note that we fit the scaler on the train set only and use it to transform the train and test set to prevent data leakage, i.e., information from the test set should not be leaked while training the model.
Looking at the average number of nodes and maximum depth of the forest:
Curious about how does a particular tree of the forest look?
To predict the class for the instances in the test set, we use predict() function.
Given an instance in the test set, what is the probability of each class it may fall in, is described by the predict_proba() function.

Note: We are interested in predicting the positive class, i.e., Built-up so we will be focusing on the probs[ : , 1] part only. We will be using it for plotting the Precision-Recall Curve in the following part of the blog.
There are several ways to evaluate our model. In which case to use which evaluation metric is indeed what makes us scratch our head!
As the name suggests, it describes the confusion that the model undergoes, while predicting the classes.
But understanding the confusion matrix itself is often confusing! Let’s understand it in the simplest way possible.
In binary classification problems, confusion matrix looks like:
True Positive (TP): Actually — Built-up, Model says — Built-up, I say, “Awesome!”
False Positive (FP): Actually — Non-Built-up, Model says — Built-up, I say, “What you feel positive, is actually negative!”
False Negative (FN): Actually — Built-up, Model says — Non-Built-up, I say, “Alas! This is the worst prediction ever.”
True Negative (TN): Actually — Non-Built-up, Model says — Non-Built-up, I say, “Finally, you came to know the fact that negativity is also a reality!”
We already know about the actual values, hence we categorize them as True and False.
We evaluate the results predicted by our model and we usually categorize “results” as Positive and Negative.
“Don’t focus on wrong predictions; focus only on the correct ones, and you will flourish.”
This is what accuracy means. For imbalanced datasets, this is, therefore, the worst way of evaluating a model.
The metrics that hold a valuable place, especially in our case:

“Precise” means minutely exact. As the name suggests, precision describes the “exactness” of a model. Out of the total predicted positives, how many are actually of our interest, is what is precision.
Recall describes the “completeness” of the model. It calculates the true positives out of the actual positives.
F1-score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall. It takes care that the contribution of precision and recall is balanced while evaluating a model.
You might have a question. Why “harmonic” mean only and not “arithmetic” or “geometric” mean? Here’s why.

According to Wikipedia, Cohen’s kappa measures the agreement between two raters who each classify N items into C mutually exclusive categories. Here is a detailed explanation of this. It can have a value between -1 and 1 with -1 signifying no agreement and 1 signifying perfect agreement. Kappa Statistic is preferably used in case of imbalanced class distribution because it doesn’t take into account, the dominating effect of the majority class.
In our case, the kappa statistic is approximately 0.74 which means there is a substantial agreement between the test set and model’s prediction. This shows that the model performs significantly well.
What’s going on under the hood?
The confusion matrix in our case looks like:
Thus, the Kappa Statistic intelligently nullifies the dominance of Non-Built-up class while evaluating the model.

Precision-Recall Curve is the plot with precision on the y-axis and recall on the x-axis for different thresholds. Area Under the Curve (AUC) is used to summarize the curve. The more the AUC, the better our model performs. This is extremely useful in our case and is commonly preferred against the ROC Curve. Everything about it is explained tremendously well in this blog which I followed.
The AUC is 0.865. This shows that our model performed well while predicting the positive class.
A deeper insight into precision and recall:
Dividing numerator and denominator with TP we get:
We know that the value of precision lies in the range [0,1].
Precision will be 0 when the ratio (FP / TP) tends to infinity, for which either FP should tend to infinity (in practice, should have very large value) or TP should be 0. We clearly don’t want this.
Precision will be 1 when the ratio (FP / TP) is 0, for which FP should be 0. Hence, this is the best case as high precision value results when the no. of false positives diminish.
Dividing numerator and denominator with TP we get:
We know that value of recall lies in the range [0,1].
Recall will be 0 when the ratio (FN / TP) tends to infinity, for which either FN should tend to infinity (in practice, should have very large value) or TP should be 0. We clearly don’t want this.

Recall will be 1 when the ratio (FN / TP) is 0, for which FN should be 0. As we know, FN is the worst prediction. Hence, this is the best case as high recall value results when the no. of false negatives diminish.
Kappa Statistic and Precision-Recall Curve worth their weight in gold when it comes to imbalanced data classification.
The train_test_split helper function doesn’t report the generalizing capability of the model since the results merely depend on one particular random split.

Also, a problem arises when we adjust the parameter settings (hyper-parameters) until we get good results. This may give a hint about the test data to the model and the model may again overfit. To prevent this, we need a “validation set” on which the trained model will be validated and then will finally be tested on the testing data, preventing it from being leaked. But this will reduce the amount of train samples drastically. This is where cross-validation comes to our rescue. It prevents the need for a validation set. See the scikit-learn documentation for this fact.
There are several cross-validation techniques, one can apply to one’s data.
I used Stratified K-fold cross-validation technique so that the relative class frequencies get approximately preserved in each train and validation fold. It is important for class imbalance case.
How does Stratified K-fold cross-validation work?

In Stratified K-fold cross-validation, the dataset is divided into K approximately equal-sized groups (folds) with each fold maintaining the class proportions as in the original dataset. Out of these K folds, K-1 folds are used to train the model and the remaining fold is used to validate the model.

Note: The parameter “shuffle” in StratifiedKFold() is set to “True” because our data is not arbitrary and it, therefore, becomes a necessity to shuffle the data before we split it. When shuffle=True, we have to set the “random_state” parameter to a random number so that it prevents the results from changing when the code gets executed multiple times.
Low standard deviation is an indication of the model not being overfitted. In addition, although marginally, the Kappa Statistic (here, 0.746) has improved than in the previous case (0.744).
In each fold, almost similar kappa statistic value and almost similar AUC value proves that our model generalizes well.
Hyper-parameters are parameters whose values are set before the commence of the learning process and are not directly learnt by the model.
Tuning the hyper-parameters aids us in the strive towards finding the ideal parameter-suite for a particular model so that it gives the best scores.
GridSearchCV and RandomizedSearchCV are most popularly used for tuning hyper-parameters.
In the upcoming part, we will attempt to unravel the optimal hyper-parameters that contribute in further improved values of the evaluation metrics discussed, using GridSearchCV.
Find the complete code at my GitHub Repository.
Hope the avid readers like it and have their say! Stay tuned for the upcoming part!
[1] Remote Sensing Tutorials — Canada Centre for Mapping and Earth Observation (or Canada Centre for remote Sensing), Natural Resources Canada.
[3] Thanh Noi, P.; Kappas, M. Comparison of Random Forest, k-Nearest Neighbor, and Support Vector Machine Classifiers for Land Cover Classification Using Sentinel-2 Imagery. Sensors 2018, 18, 18.
[4] Blogs: Machine Learning Mastery, Have you asked why F1-Score is a Harmonic Mean(HM) of Precision and Recall?

A techie who aspires to become Data Science savvy. Currently, a Machine Learning practitioner on Earth Observation data at Space Applications Centre, ISRO.
